title: heidi_basics
text: successfully simulate using HeiDI, requirements data.frame specifying groups, phases, trials experiment, (optionally, although recommended), data.frame saliency parameters stimuli experiment.

title: heidi_basics
text: -called design data.frame, user specifies experimental design. rules data.frame: 0 - row represents group. 1 - first column contains group labels. 2 - remaining columns organized pairs. first column pair specifies trials give phase, whereas second column pair specifies whether trials within phase randomized. Let’s build design matrix. Fairly simple! observations trial notation: 0 - Trials preceded number. number represents number times trial given phase. “10A(US)” means “(US)” trial given 10 times. 1 - presence absence unconditioned stimulus (US) denoted traditional “+” “-” symbols. Instead, use parenthesis denote “named” stimuli. can thought single element complex name (.e., one character). , “(US)” denotes single element representing US. 2 - “/” character used trial separator (imply randomization ). Thus, “1A/1B” specifies single “” trial single “B” trial given phase. Randomization trials specified columns. ever want check trials string work simulator, can use trial_parser. function returns list trial_names (name trial), trial_repeats (number times trial given), trial_list (list components trial), stimuli (stimuli found trial string).
code: my_blocking <- data.frame(Group = c("Exp", "Control"),                           Phase1 = c("10A(US)", "10C(US)"),                           R1 = c(FALSE, FALSE),                           Phase2 = c("10AB(US)", "10AB(US)"),                           R2 = c(FALSE, FALSE),                           Test = c("1A/1B", "1A/1B"),                           R3 = c(FALSE, FALSE)) my_blocking #>     Group  Phase1    R1   Phase2    R2  Test    R3 #> 1     Exp 10A(US) FALSE 10AB(US) FALSE 1A/1B FALSE #> 2 Control 10C(US) FALSE 10AB(US) FALSE 1A/1B FALSE trial_parser("AB/10AC")  #not specifying a number of AB trials. Bad practice! #> $trial_names #> [1] "AB" "AC" #>  #> $trial_repeats #> [1]  1 10 #>  #> $trial_list #> $trial_list[[1]] #> [1] "A" "B" #>  #> $trial_list[[2]] #> [1] "A" "C" #>  #>  #> $is_test #> $is_test[[1]] #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $is_test[[2]] #> [1] FALSE #>  #>  #> $stimuli #> [1] "A" "B" "C" trial_parser("10AB(AB)(US)") #considering a configural cue for elements AB #> $trial_names #> [1] "AB(AB)(US)" #>  #> $trial_repeats #> [1] 10 #>  #> $trial_list #> $trial_list[[1]] #> [1] "A"  "B"  "AB" "US" #>  #>  #> $is_test #> $is_test[[1]] #> [1] FALSE #>  #>  #> $stimuli #> [1] "A"  "B"  "AB" "US"

title: heidi_basics
text: able run simulation experiment data.frame, simulation function use default saliency values stimulus. Whenever want specific saliency values stimuli experiment, pass data.frame parameters stimuli. Let’s specify table experiment.
code: my_pars <- data.frame(Stimulus = c("A", "B", "C", "US"), Alpha = c(0.3, 0.3, 0.3, 0.5)) my_pars #>   Stimulus Alpha #> 1        A   0.3 #> 2        B   0.3 #> 3        C   0.3 #> 4       US   0.5

previous_headings: Using heidi in R > The parameters table
title: heidi_basics
text: final ingredient list simulation options. can get default one get_heidi_opts, modify accordingly.
code: my_opts <- get_heidi_opts() my_opts #> $iterations #> [1] 1 #>  #> $miniblocks #> [1] TRUE my_opts$iterations <- 10 my_opts #> $iterations #> [1] 10 #>  #> $miniblocks #> [1] TRUE

previous_headings: Using heidi in R > The parameters table
title: heidi_basics
text: can finally simulate model run_heidi. default, function returns list relevant data. Let’s see.
code: my_sim <- run_heidi(design_df = my_blocking,                    param_df = my_pars,                    options = my_opts) names(my_sim) #contains information about weights (ws), v-values (vs), and r-values (rs) #> [1] "ws" "vs" "rs" "as" head(my_sim$vs) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>   group   trial phase  trial_type v_type  s1    s2    block_size value #>   <fct>   <int> <fct>  <fct>      <fct>   <fct> <fct>      <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Control     1 Phase1 C(US)      chain_v C     US             1 0     #> 2 Control     1 Phase1 C(US)      comb_v  C     US             1 0     #> 3 Control     2 Phase1 C(US)      chain_v C     US             1 0     #> 4 Control     2 Phase1 C(US)      comb_v  C     US             1 0.172 #> 5 Control     3 Phase1 C(US)      chain_v C     US             1 0     #> 6 Control     3 Phase1 C(US)      comb_v  C     US             1 0.312

title: heidi_basics
text: , rarely want raw data. like , want see plots. Let’s use make_plots create plots, patch_plots display .
code: my_plots = make_plots(my_sim) plot_names = names(my_plots) plot_names #>  [1] "Control: Rs"       "Control: Ws"       "Control: Vs"       #>  [4] "Control: Vs (bar)" "Control: As"       "Exp: Rs"           #>  [7] "Exp: Ws"           "Exp: Vs"           "Exp: Vs (bar)"     #> [10] "Exp: As" patch_plots(plots = my_plots, selection = plot_names[c(3, 6)]) #> geom_path: Each group consists of only one observation. Do you need to adjust #> the group aesthetic? #> geom_path: Each group consists of only one observation. Do you need to adjust #> the group aesthetic? #> geom_path: Each group consists of only one observation. Do you need to adjust #> the group aesthetic? #> geom_path: Each group consists of only one observation. Do you need to adjust #> the group aesthetic?

title: heidi_math
text: HeiDI model four major components: 1) acquisition reciprocal associations stimuli, 2) pooling associations activate stimulus representations, 3) distribution activations stimulus-specific response units, 4) generation responses.

title: heidi_math
text: Whenever trial given, HeiDI learns associations among stimuli. association two stimuli, \(\) \(j\) denoted via \(v_{,j}\). association \(v_{,j}\) represents directional expectation: expectation \(j\) presented \(\). Furthermore, value represents nature effect \(\) representation \(j\). positive, presentation \(\) “excites” representation \(j\). negative, presentation \(\) “inhibits” representation \(j\). HeiDI learns “forward” associations stimuli, also reciprocal, “backward” associations. Thus, organisms presented \(\rightarrow j\), organisms learn \(v_{,j}\), also \(v_{j, }\), expectation receiving \(\) presented \(j\). Note , sake brevity, learning equations specified forward associations.

previous_headings: The mathematics behind HeiDI > 1 - Acquiring reciprocal associations
title: heidi_math
text: HeiDI generates expectations stimuli. expectation stimulus \(j\) (\(e_j\)) expressed \[ \tag{Eq. 1} e_j  = \sum_{k}^{K}x_kv_{k,j} \] \(K\) set containing stimuli experiment, \(x_k\) quantity denoting presence absence stimulus \(k\) (1 0, respectively)1.

previous_headings: The mathematics behind HeiDI > 1 - Acquiring reciprocal associations
title: heidi_math
text: HeiDI learns appropriate expectations via error-correction mechanisms. trial \(t\), association stimuli \(\) \(j\) expressed \[ \tag{Eq. 2} v_{,j, t} = v_{,j, t-1} + \Delta v_{,j, t} \] \(v_{j,, t-1}\) forward association \(\) \(j\) trial \(t-1\), \(\Delta v_{,j, t}\) change association result trial \(t\). delta term uses pooled error term expressed \[ \tag{Eq. 3} \Delta v_{,j} = x_i\alpha_i(x_jc\alpha_j - e_j) \] \(\alpha_i\) \(\alpha_j\) parameters representing salience stimuli \(\) \(j\), respectively (\(0 \le \alpha \le 1\)), \(c\) scaling constant (\(c = 1\)). Note term denoting trial, \(t\) omitted simplicity.

title: heidi_math
text: HeiDI pools stimulus associations activate stimulus-specific representations. activation representation stimulus \(j\), \(a_j\), defined : \[ \tag{Eq. 4} a_{j,M} = o_{j,M} + h_{j,M} \] \(o_{j,M}\) denotes combined associative strength towards stimulus \(j\) presence stimuli \(M\), \(h_{j,M}\) denotes chained associative strength towards stimulus \(j\) presence stimuli \(M\).

previous_headings: The mathematics behind HeiDI > 2 - Pooling the strength of associations
title: heidi_math
text:
quantity \(o_{j,M}\) result combining associative strength forwards backwards associations stimulus \(j\) \[ 	ag{Eq. 5} o_{j,M} = \sum_{m 
eq j}^{M}v_{m,j} + \left( rac{\sum_{m 
eq j}^{M}v_{m,j} \sum_{m 
eq j}^{M}v_{j,m}}{c}ight) \] sums run stimuli \(M\) presented trial, also different stimulus \(j\).2 left hand term describes forward associations stimuli \(M\) \(j\) affect representation \(j\), whereas right hand term describes backward associations \(j\) stimuli \(M\) affect representation (although modulated forward associations ).

previous_headings: The mathematics behind HeiDI > 2 - Pooling the strength of associations
title: heidi_math
text: quantity \(h_{j,M}\) captures indirect associative strength stimuli \(M\) \(j\), via absent stimuli. , \(h_{j,M}\) defined \[ \tag{Eq. 6} h_{j,M} = \sum_{m \neq j}^{M} \sum_{n}^{N}\frac{v_{m,n}o_{j,n}}{c} \] N stimuli presented trial (.e., K-M). Note re-use \(o\), quantity defined Eq. 5. equation allows absent stimuli \(N\) influence representation stimulus \(j\), long association present stimuli \(M\).

what: 3 - Distributing strength into stimulus-specific response units
title: heidi_math
text: HeiDI distributes pooled stimulus-specific strength among \(K\) stimuli, according relative salience. activation response unit \(j\), \(R_j\) expressed \[ \tag{Eq. 7} R_j = \frac{\theta(j)}{\sum_{k}^{K}\theta(k)}a_{j,M} \] \(K\) can include present absent stimuli, \(\theta\) function returns salience stimulus \(k\) depending whether absent (.e., \(k \N\)) (.e., \(k \M\)), \[ \tag{Eq. 8} \theta(k) =  \begin{cases}     \left| \sum_{m}^{M}\left( v_{m,k}+\sum_{n \neq k}^{N}\frac{v_{m,n}v_{n,k}}{c}\right) \right|,& \text{} k \N\\     \alpha_k, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \] Note quantity absent stimuli absolute, order prevent negative \(\theta\) values due inhibitory associations3 4. Also note summation term used left-hand side expression absent stimulus. implies present stimuli \(M\) contribute salience stimulus \(k\). Finally, note right side expression present stimuli contribute via direct association \(k\), \(v_{m,k}\), also associative chains absent stimuli (c.f., Eq. 6).

title: heidi_math
text: Finally, HeiDI responds. response-generating mechanisms HeiDI currently underspecified. current version, HeiDI’s responses product activation stimulus-specific response units connection units specific motor units. , activation motor unit \(q\), \(r_q\), given \[ \tag{Eq. 9} r_q = R_jw_{j,q} \] \(w_{j,q}\) weight representing association stimulus-specific unit \(j\) motor unit \(q\).

title: Authors and Citation
text: Victor Navarro. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Navarro V (2022). heidi: R-based HeiDI simulator. https://github.com/victor-navarro/heidi, http://victornavarro.org/heidi/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {heidi: An R-based HeiDI simulator},   author = {Victor Navarro},   year = {2022},   note = {https://github.com/victor-navarro/heidi, http://victornavarro.org/heidi/}, }

title: An R-based HeiDI simulator
text: R Package Simulate Acquisition Expression Reciprocal Associations

title: An R-based HeiDI simulator
text: devtools, install . install.packages("devtools") , can install directly repository via devtools::install_github("victor-navarro/heidi", build_vignettes = TRUE) managed build vignettes, ’s vignette showing basics package vignette("heidi_basics", package = "heidi") better yet, launch visual interface via
code: library(heidi) heidi_app()

what: Get options for heidi model — get_heidi_opts
title: Get options for heidi model — get_heidi_opts
text: Get options heidi model

title: Get options for heidi model — get_heidi_opts
code: get_heidi_opts(iterations = 1, miniblocks = TRUE)

title: Get options for heidi model — get_heidi_opts
text: iterations integer denoting number iterations run. Default = 1. miniblocks logical denoting whether create trial miniblocks possible. Default = TRUE.

title: Get options for heidi model — get_heidi_opts

what: An assortment of functions to help heidi — heidi_helpers

text: gen_ss_weights generates named array model weights. parse_ws, parse_vs, parse_rs parse_heidi_results parse raw outputs trainPavHEIDI readable format.

title: An assortment of functions to help heidi — heidi_helpers
code: gen_ss_weights(stims, default_val = 0)  parse_ws(mod)  parse_vs(mod)  parse_rs(mod)  parse_as(mod)  parse_heidi_results(raw_results)  filter_heidi_results(parsed_results, filters)

title: An assortment of functions to help heidi — heidi_helpers
text: stims character vector stimuli. default_val Default alpha value. mod model list, returned trainPavHEIDI. raw_results tibble model information, returned run_heidi parsed_results list parsed results, returned parse_heidi_results filters named list containing "phase" "trial_type" character vectors, filtering data.

code: make_plots(dat)  plot_ws(vals)  plot_vs(vals, bars = F)  plot_rs(vals)  plot_as(vals)  patch_plots(plots, selection, options = get_plot_opts())  get_plot_opts(common_scale = TRUE)  plot_common_scale(plots)

title: Plotting functions for heidi models — heidi_plots
text: dat list containing data.frames parsed weights, r values, v values, returned parse_heidi_results. vals data.frame containing parsed values bars logical stipulating whether summarize use stacked bars, instead points lines. plots named list plots selection character vector selected plots options list options common_scale logical. Whether plot data common y-scale.

title: Make a tibble to fit a heidi model — make_heidi_args
code: make_heidi_args(design, pars, opts)

title: Make a tibble to fit a heidi model — make_heidi_args
text: design design list, returned parse_design pars parameter data.frame returned get_params opts list options

title: Make a tibble to fit a heidi model — make_heidi_args
text: tibble arguments required run model. row represents group experimental design.

title: Make a tibble to fit a heidi model — make_heidi_args
code: df <- data.frame(Group = c('Group 1', 'Group 2'), P1 = c('10AB(US)', '10A(US)'), R1 = c(TRUE, TRUE)) des <- parse_design(df) ps <- get_params(des, 0.2) make_heidi_args(design = des, pars = ps, opts = get_heidi_opts(iterations = 1)) #> # A tibble: 2 × 11 #> # Rowwise:  iteration #>   iteration group   tps    train  phase block_size trials trial_names stim_names #>       <int> <chr>   <list> <list> <lis> <list>     <list> <list>      <list>     #> 1         1 Group 1 <int>  <lgl>  <chr> <dbl [10]> <list> <chr [2]>   <chr [3]>  #> 2         1 Group 2 <int>  <lgl>  <chr> <dbl [10]> <list> <chr [2]>   <chr [2]>  #> # … with 2 more variables: stim_alphas <list>, stim_cons <list>

title: Run the HeiDI model — run_heidi
text: Runs model given data.frame containing experimental design parameters.

title: Run the HeiDI model — run_heidi
code: run_heidi(design_df, param_df = NULL, options = NULL, parse = T)

title: Run the HeiDI model — run_heidi
text: design_df data.frame dimensions G,2*P+1; G number groups P number phases. param_df data.frame dimensions N,2; N number stimuli experimental design. options list options, returned get_heidi_opts. parse logical specifying whether results parsed. Default = TRUE.

title: Run the HeiDI model — run_heidi
text: list parsed results tibble raw results

title: Run the HeiDI model — run_heidi
text: specification design_df adhere following rules: first column specify Group names remaining columns paired, pair denoting single experimental phase. first containing trial strings (see ) logicals denoting whether trials randomized . Trial strings use specific syntax. Take string "30AX(US)/10A", example. "/" character used denote different trials. , string specifies two trial types. Parentheses used denote complex stimuli (stimuli need specifically named). , US named stimulus. numbers beginning trial type denote number trials given within phase.

title: Trains a Pavlovian HeiDI — train_pav_heidi
text: Trains Pavlovian HeiDI

title: Trains a Pavlovian HeiDI — train_pav_heidi
code: train_pav_heidi(   sals,   cons,   w,   tps,   trials,   trial_names = NULL,   phase = NULL,   block_size = NULL,   train = rep(TRUE, length(tps)),   targets = "US" )

title: Trains a Pavlovian HeiDI — train_pav_heidi
text: sals named vector stimulus saliencies. cons named vector stimulus constants. w named array dimensions S,S; S number stimuli. tps vector trial pointers training, function trials. trials list length T, character vectors specifying stimuli involved trial. T number unique trials experiment. trial_names (optional) character vector length T names trials phase (optional) character vector length T names phases block_size (optional) integer vector length T specifying block size per trial train (optional) logical vector specifying whether trial result learning (update w). Helpful tests. targets character vector specifying target stimulus trial. development. now, just US.

title: Trains a Pavlovian HeiDI — train_pav_heidi
text: list ws - array dimensions P,S,S; P number trials used train model S number stimuli involved experiment. rs,combvs, chainvs - Lists length P r-values, combination vs, chain vs. tps, trials, trial_names, phase, block_size -  Carryover processing. See Arguments.

title: Trains a Pavlovian HeiDI — train_pav_heidi
text: array w contains associations stimuli involved experiment. Entry ,j specifies associative strength stimulus stimulus j. Entry j,specifies opposite direction.

what: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
title: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
text: Parses string stipulating trials

title: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
code: trial_parser(str)

title: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
text: str string

title: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
text: list number trials, trials, stimulus names

title: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
text: Supports complex stimuli parentheses (e.g., "5A(US)") Supports probe trials, followed hash (e.g., "3X#")

title: Parses a string stipulating trials — trial_parser
code: trial_parser("30XAU/30(YA)A") #> $trial_names #> [1] "XAU"   "(YA)A" #>  #> $trial_repeats #> [1] 30 30 #>  #> $trial_list #> $trial_list[[1]] #> [1] "X" "A" "U" #>  #> $trial_list[[2]] #> [1] "A"  "YA" #>  #>  #> $is_test #> $is_test[[1]] #> [1] FALSE #>  #> $is_test[[2]] #> [1] FALSE #>  #>  #> $stimuli #> [1] "X"  "A"  "U"  "YA" #>  trial_parser("1X#/2X(US)#") #> $trial_names #> [1] "X#"     "X(US)#" #>  #> $trial_repeats #> [1] 1 2 #>  #> $trial_list #> $trial_list[[1]] #> [1] "X" #>  #> $trial_list[[2]] #> [1] "X"  "US" #>  #>  #> $is_test #> $is_test[[1]] #> [1] TRUE #>  #> $is_test[[2]] #> [1] TRUE #>  #>  #> $stimuli #> [1] "X"  "US" #>
